newsitem.title: VIETNAM: Microsoft says software piracy rife in Vietnam.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft says software piracy rife in Vietnam.

text.p: U.S. computer giant Microsoft said on Wednesday that 99 percent of software in Vietnam was pirated and urged Hanoi to speed efforts to resolve the problem.

Microsoft's General Manager in Vietnam, Michael Davis, told Reuters a new industry survey showed the level of copyright violations in Vietnam exceeded that in China and was causing substantial losses for producers.
"These new numbers are not very encouraging," he said in a telephone interview.
"Based on information we've received from new Business Software Alliance estimates we know it's (the losses) significant," he said.
Davis said products such as Microsoft's MS Office were popular piracy targets, but operating systems such as Windows and DOS were relatively unaffected by the problem.
He said Hanoi was working on laws to resolve the problem but said the necessary regulations were not yet in place.
Microsoft's products retail in Vietnam at around the same price as in the United States. Windows 95 and Office 95 are available in Vietnamese language editions.
Vietnam is one of the world's poorest countries. According to recent World Bank estimates, per capita income is around $275 per year.
Despite this, computer sales are growing fast. Davis estimated that around 100,000 had been sold this year.

Vietnam issued a copyright law on July 1 and a decree on implementation was announced earlier this week. However, legal experts who have seen the decree say it contains no apparent reference to the protection of foreign works.
